Yep, that is the case.  Our functional tests test the entire system,
end-to-end.  Because of this, the setup code is usually pretty big.  We have
to load the system, load the needed files, initialize everything, etc.  

We could put this in a setUp method and break our tests out into smaller
test methods, but that would make the test slower and harder to read.  As it
is now, it's pretty easy to see what's going on in the functional tests.
The simplest thing in terms of maintenance and readability is to keep our
test methods big.

Our unit tests tend to be smaller (102 tests, 259 assertions).

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: Tuesday, July 17, 2001 8:32 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?


    > Di Iorio, Matthew (ISS Atlanta) wrote:
    > > As an aside, we count asserts instead of tests becase it's a
    > > finer grained metric.  Right now we only have 8 functional
    > > test methods, but 170 assertions.  When we add to a functional
    > > test we don't create a new test method, we add some more
    > > assertions to an already existing test.  It would be harder to
    > > see progress if we tracked test cases.
    > 
    > I'd like to argue against this.  Having many assertions per test
    > makes it more difficult to see where the problem is.

In defense of Matthew, it sounds like his tests are functional tests using
JUnit, not unit tests.  In which case it MAY make sense to group asserts
together in some homogenized fashion.

Is this true Matthew?

-Jason
